13. Weinstein (1981) performs a similar calculation for monetary policy usingmultipliers derived from the Hickman—Cohen model and finds a large potentialeffect of the monetary expansion in 1934 and 1935. However, he emphasizeschat the National Industrial Recovery Act acted as a negative supply shock andcounteracted the monetary expansion. While the NIRA may indeed have stuntedthe recovery somewhat, it does not follow from this that monetary policy wasunimportant to the recovery. In the absence of the monetary expansion, thesupply shock cou'd have led to continued decline rather than to the rapidgrowth of real output that actually occurred.14. At some level it might not matter if money growth rates rose in responseto output growth because one could argue that the monetary authorities alwayshad the option of holding money growth rates at their usual level.
